title: How to Create the Golden Hour Look in VSCO on Android

steps.headline: Take a photo of your subject facing the sun.
steps.description: Even if it’s not that golden time of the evening, you’ll want to start with a photo of your subject illuminated by light. If no daylight is available, point an indoor light at the subject instead. You can take the photo with any app, including VSCO.

steps.headline: Open VSCO.
steps.description: If the app isn’t already open, tap the white icon containing a black circle on the home screen or in the app drawer.

steps.headline: Tap the two overlapping squares.
steps.description: It’s in the icon bar at the bottom of the screen. This opens your Studio, which is where you’ll find all photos you’ve edited or taken with VSCO.

steps.headline: Tap the photo you want to give the golden hour effect.
steps.description: The photo is now highlighted. If you don’t see the photo, you’ll have to import it. Tap + at the top-right corner, select the photo from your Android’s gallery, then tap Import.

steps.headline: Tap the Editing icon.
steps.description: It’s the two slider knobs at the bottom of the screen. This opens your photo editing tools.

steps.headline: Select either K2 (Paid) or M5 (Free).
steps.description: K2 is a premium filter available to VSCO users with paid memberships. If you’re a free user, select M5. If you want to use K2 and haven’t ever been a paid subscriber, you’ll see a message prompting you to start a free trial. Follow the on-screen instructions to do so if you wish. If you don’t cancel your membership before the end of the trial period, you’ll be charged by the Play Store.

steps.headline: Slightly lower the exposure level.
steps.description:
The amount you lower it depends on your photo. Here’s how:
Tap the two slider knobs to open the editing options. Tap Exposure (the sun icon). Drag the slider knob a little to the left to darken the image a touch. Tap the check mark to save.

steps.headline: Increase the contrast.
steps.description:
You’ll want to increase this just enough to emulate the dramatic shadows cast by the sun. Here’s how:
Tap Contrast (the two-toned circle). Drag the slider knob to the right until you’re satisfied. Tap the check mark to save.

steps.headline: Increase the saturation level.
steps.description:
This makes the colors look more vivid. Here’s how:
Tap the Saturation tool. Drag the slider to the right until the colors look like they are lit up by the sun. Tap the check mark.

steps.headline: Add orange highlights.
steps.description:
Casting your photo with orange highlights makes the subject and surroundings look illuminated by sun. Here’s how:
Tap the highlights tint icon. It’s the raindrop icon with an ″h″ inside. Tap the orange circle at the bottom-left. Move the slider knob to the right to increase orange highlighting until you’re satisfied. You can also increase the yellow if you’d like. To do so, tap the yellow circle, then drag the slider. Tap the check mark to save.

steps.headline: Readjust contrast, saturation, and exposure settings (optional).
steps.description: If you realized you increase or decrease any of the settings you adjusted before playing with the highlighting tool, return to any of these tools, then add or decrease its strength.

steps.headline: Tap Save.
steps.description: It’s at the top-right corner. Your photo is now saved with the golden hour effect.

If no daylight is available, point an indoor light at the subject instead. You can take the photo with any app, including VSCO. Open VSCO. If the app isn’t already open, tap the white icon containing a black circle on the home screen or in the app drawer. Tap the two overlapping squares. It’s in the icon bar at the bottom of the screen. Tap the two slider knobs to open the editing options. Tap Exposure (the sun icon). Drag the slider knob a little to the left to darken the image a touch. Tap the check mark to save. Increase the contrast. You’ll want to increase this just enough to emulate the dramatic shadows cast by the sun. Here’s how:
Tap Contrast (the two-toned circle). Drag the slider knob to the right until you’re satisfied. Tap the check mark to save. Increase the saturation level. This makes the colors look more vivid. Here’s how:

Tap the highlights tint icon. It’s the raindrop icon with an ″h″ inside. Tap the orange circle at the bottom-left. Move the slider knob to the right to increase orange highlighting until you’re satisfied. You can also increase the yellow if you’d like. To do so, tap the yellow circle, then drag the slider.
